text.p: The following are the reports carried by Estonia's newspapers on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these reports and does not vouch for their accuracy:

- Claims about a split in the Coalition Party are caused by a competition between its chairman Tiit Vahi and Prime Minister Mart Siimann for the leader's post, Mart Kubo, a member of the party's board, said.

- Russia has stopped making allegations about human rights violations in Estonia and is prepared to cooperate in ethnic issues, Minister of Ethnic Affairs Andra Veidemann said after a meeting with her Russian counterpart Vyacheslav Mikhaylov in Moscow. Veidemann predicts an improvement in Estonian-Russian relations.
- Estonia hopes to join the European Union in 7-10 years, but expects the negotiations will be long and difficult, Foreign Minister Toomas Ilves said in Washington on Wednesday.
- The government made a mistake by refusing a residence permit to Vladimir Prokhorov, a retired Russian officer who has been married to an Estonian for 25 years, Prime Minister Mart Siimann said.
- Riho Laanemae, Estonian charge d'affaires to the Czech Republic, will start preparations for opening the Estonian embassy in Prague in August.
- Valika, the company that regulated parking in central Tallinn, made mistakes and withheld profits it should have turned over to the city, deputy mayor of Tallinn Kalev Kallo said.

- The Russian foreign ministry on Tuesday slammed the recent assembly of the Unrepresented Nations Organisation, held in Estonia, for inciting separatist movements in Russia. Three resolutions approved by the assembly criticised the treatment of minorities in Russia.
